#Text=John St. Leger ( died 1596 )
#Text=Arms of St Leger of
#Text=Annery , Devon : Azure fretty argent , a chief or [ 1 ]
#Text=Sir John St Leger ( died 1596 ) , of Annery in the parish of Monkleigh , Devon , was an English landowner who served in local and national government .
#Text=Origins
#Text=He was the son of Sir George St Leger ( c.1475-1536 ) , of Annery , by his wife , Anne Knyvett , daughter of Sir Edmund Knyvett of Buckenham [ 2 ] and his wife Eleanor Tyrrell .
#Text=His paternal grandparents were Sir James St Leger , of Shipton , and Lady Anne Butler , heiress of Annery , daughter of Thomas Butler , 7th Earl of Ormonde and great-aunt of Queen Anne Boleyn .
#Text=One of his great-uncles was Sir Thomas St Leger ( c.1440-1483 ) , the husband of Anne of York , Duchess of Exeter ( 1439-1476 ) , sister of Kings Edward IV and Richard III .
#Text=His great-grandfather was Sir John St Leger ( c.1404-1442 ) lord of the manor of Ulcombe in Kent , whose three sons Ralph , Thomas and James , all made advantageous marriages .

#Text=The manor of Ulcombe had been held by the family from the See of Canterbury from shortly after the Norman Conquest of 1066 , during which a St Leger knight is supposed by tradition to have supported William the Conqueror with his hand on disembarking from his ship at Pevensey . [ 3 ]
#Text=Public career

#Text=Knighted in 1544 and Sheriff of Devon in 1560 , he was Member of Parliament for Dartmouth , Devon , in 1555-1558 , Devon in 1559 – 1563 , Arundel , Sussex , in 1563-1571 , Devon again in 1571-1583 and Tregony , Cornwall in 1584-1585 . [ 4 ]
#Text=Landholdings
#Text=Under a royal grant dated 10 June 1543 " John St Leger , King 's servant " acquired the following former monastic lands following the Dissolution of the Monasteries : [ 5 ]
#Text=Canonsleigh Priory
#Text=in the parish of Burlescombe , site and demesne of .
#Text=Priory manor of Hockworthy .
#Text=Torre Abbey
#Text=, site and demesne of , subject to a 21-year lease granted at Dissolution to Hugh I Pollard of King 's Nympton . [ 6 ]
#Text=St Leger sold it in 1543 to Hugh Pollard . [ 7 ]
#Text=Manor of Cullompton , formerly held by Buckland Abbey .
#Text=Manor of Upton Weaver ( or Higher Upton ) in the parish of Cullompton , formerly held by St Nicholas ' Priory , Exeter .
#Text=Other non-monastic property in Devon
#Text=Small landholding in Cornwall .
#Text=The lands were exchanged with the king for other lands of St Leger , with an excess balance paid by him of £116 9s 9d . [ 8 ]
#Text=Marriage and children

#Text=He married Catherine Neville , daughter of George Neville , 5th Baron Bergavenny and his third wife Lady Mary Stafford , youngest daughter of Edward Stafford , 3rd Duke of Buckingham and his wife Lady Eleanor Percy .
#Text=Their children included :
#Text=John St Leger , said to be a soldier in Ireland who died unmarried and in poverty
#Text=16th century mural monument of Richard Bellew of Ash [ 9 ] and his wife Margaret St Leger of Annery [ 10 ] in Braunton Church , Devon

#Text=Mary St Leger , who married Sir Richard Grenville ( 1542-1591 ) of Stowe , Kilkhampton , Cornwall and Bideford , Devon , the famous captain of Revenge , and was mother of Sir Bernard Grenville .
#Text=Frances St Leger , who married John Stucley ( 1551-1611 ) , of Affeton , Devon [ 11 ] and was the mother of Sir Lewis Stucley [ 12 ]
#Text=Margaret St Leger , who married Richard Bellew of Ash , Braunton and Alverdiscott , Devon .
#Text=A heraldic mural monument to Richard Bellew and his wife Margaret St Leger survives in Braunton parish Church .

#Text=Eulalia St Leger , who married firstly Edmund Tremayne of Collacombe in the parish of Lamerton , Devon , and secondly Tristram Arscott ( 1544-1621 ) of Tetcott , Devon , the latter who bought Annery from his father-in-law John St Leger . [ 11 ] [ 13 ]
#Text=Death
#Text=Despite accumulating much land , he became encumbered with debts and parted with many of his estates .
#Text=He died " a poor man " [ 4 ] and on the death of his son John without children the St Leger family of Annery was extinguished .

#Text=However , another line descended from Ralph St Leger ( d.1470 ) , Sheriff of Kent and it was one of his great uncles , father of Sir Anthony St Leger ( d.1559 ) , KG , Lord Deputy of Ireland , whose descendants were created Viscount Doneraile , who later inherited the manor of Eggesford in Devon .
